Headline: The beautiful creations of Japanese chef Takehiro Kishimoto
Article_Body:
Edible art: Chef by day and food carving Instagrammer by night, Takehiro Kishimoto practices mukimono -- the Japanese art of carving decorative garnishing -- as well as Thai carving.  Gaku Carving: The chef founded Instagram account Gaku Carving in 2016. It's since amassed more than 280,000 followers. Challenging mediums: "Even with the same ingredient, each fruit or vegetable has a different shape and softness. It took me five years to overcome and understand the art," says Takehiro.  Tempura Pokemon balls: The Kobe-based chef says he always eats what he carves, often using it to create tempura. 
 Life-long student: It took Takehiro about five years to master the art of food carving, he says. These days, he's dabbling in Chinese carving styles.  Colors of nature: Takehiro says his love of food carving stems from his appreciation for the colors of nature.  Inspired by produce: "I often go to the vegetable section in the market to check out produce and imagine what they can become before carving them," says Takehiro.
